summaries.factual_summary: In the morning at The Wayward Compass in Ardenford’s Middle Tier, Bazgar (a Rakthok orc from the Dakmarnak) arrived, ordered food, and sized up the room for potential allies. A mix-up with meal orders drew Bazgar, Marwen Ashcroft, and the veiled elf Sabriel together at one table, where they introduced themselves and compared backgrounds and skills. The trio reviewed the inn’s writ board and chose the time-sensitive “Border Patrol — Undead Sighting” job, then asked the barkeep Thorgrim Ledger-Scar for directions to Renn Caldor at the Eastern Patrol watchtower. Sabriel paid Thorgrim to stable their pony (with extra cost for “whole grains”), and the new party set out toward the eastern hills.
summaries.narrative_seed: Warm smoke and old stone filled the Wayward Compass as a grinning southern orc swaggered in looking for stew—and found, instead, strangers worth betting his life on. A botched set of plates became an excuse to share a table, trade names, and quietly measure one another’s usefulness, until the writ board’s sealed notice about undead on the eastern road pulled them into common purpose. With Thorgrim’s blunt directions and a freshly paid stable fee, the three stepped back into Ardenford’s morning wind and started climbing toward the watchtower.
key_events: Bazgar entered The Wayward Compass, ordered food, and scanned the room for capable adventurers.
Bazgar, Marwen, and Sabriel were brought together by a mistaken food delivery and shared a table, exchanging introductions and travel origins.
Sabriel removed their veil to eat, drawing immediate attention from the room due to their striking, unusual elven appearance; they then tried to keep a lower profile.
The trio examined the writ board postings (sheep raids, spider clearance, and an undead sighting) and agreed to take the Border Patrol undead job first because it was time-sensitive.
They approached the barkeep, Thorgrim Ledger-Scar, who clarified the contact was Renn Caldor and gave directions to the Eastern Patrol watchtower outside the city.
Sabriel arranged stabling for their pony at the inn, paying extra for special feed, and the party departed toward the eastern hills.

character_moments.Marwen Ashcroft: Revealed interest in harvesting reagents from dangerous creatures (especially spiders) and signaled she could contribute in non-brute-force ways while remaining cautious about attention and reputation.
character_moments.Sabriel: Chose to remove their veil to eat despite the social risk, then re-covered to avoid drawing attention; also positioned themselves as a healer/patcher and supported taking the urgent undead patrol job.
character_moments.Thorgrim Ledger-Scar: Enforced the inn’s practical, no-nonsense tone—corrected the name confusion, provided clear directions to the Eastern Patrol, and grumbled about elven fussiness while accepting payment for stabling.

summaries.factual_summary: Bazgar, Marwen, and Sabriel leave Ardenford in the morning and hike east toward the Eastern Patrol watchtower to follow up on the undead sighting job. The route climbs worn hills into increasingly dense forest, and the watchtower—visible at first—disappears behind the canopy as they continue upward. Marwen releases her ferret, Flicker, to scout ahead intermittently, and the party reaches the tower’s stone entry and calls up before entering. They ascend the tight, single-file stairs to the observation platform, where they find Renn Caldor on duty wearing his grandfather’s war medal.
summaries.narrative_seed: Morning light gives way to shadowed green as the party trades Ardenford’s stone and salt air for a steep forest hike. A lone crow keeps pace overhead while Flicker darts through brush and returns to shoulders like a living compass. The watchtower arrives suddenly—stone rising out of trees—its narrow stair built for defense, leading them up to a waiting scout with grief and duty hanging from a medal at his throat.

Marwen lets her ferret, Flicker, range ahead as a casual scout; Flicker repeatedly returns to the party and briefly rides on Bazgar’s shoulder.
The watchtower’s stone wall appears abruptly out of the trees; the party calls up for permission and is invited inside rather than entering unannounced.
They climb the tower’s narrow, defensive stairs single-file and reach the broad observation platform, spotting Renn Caldor on duty with his grandfather’s war medal prominently worn.

summaries.factual_summary: On the Eastern Patrol watchtower’s top platform, the party meets border scout Renn Caldor, who explains he believes his long-dead grandfather, Corwin Caldor, may be among recently sighted undead drifting toward Ardenford. Renn describes the undead as war-remnants tied to Calderon Imperium necromancy, often wandering “home” without direction, and asks the party to put them to rest and identify Corwin by his Ridgeward Battalion markings. At Sabriel’s compassionate request, Renn entrusts the party with his grandfather’s war medal as a token to help recognize or reach the undead. Renn points out where he regularly sees movement across the valley and gives instructions on when he’ll be on duty for their return.
summaries.narrative_seed: Morning light washes the watchtower platform, but Renn Caldor’s grief makes the air feel colder than the wind. He speaks of a battlefield that never truly ended—bones that still try to march home, and a grandmother’s final wish that now rests on strangers’ shoulders. With solemn care, he places a battered war medal into the party’s hands and points toward the valley where the dead still move.
key_events: The party meets Renn Caldor on the observation platform and learns the undead sighting is personal: Renn believes his grandfather Corwin is among them, and he wants the remains properly laid to rest.
Renn explains the undead are likely a lingering consequence of Calderon Imperium wartime necromancy—fallen soldiers reanimating and wandering toward “home” without orders.
Sabriel requests to borrow Corwin’s war medal to help identify or calm the undead; Renn removes it and hands it over with ceremonial reverence.

Renn indicates a specific area across the valley where he frequently sees movement and notes steep cliffs may be trapping the undead there; he also clarifies his guard rotation and when the party can find him again.

character_moments.Renn Caldor: Despite being on duty and visibly grief-stricken, Renn chooses trust—handing over his grandfather’s medal and focusing on giving clear directions so Corwin can finally be found and buried.
character_moments.Sabriel: Leads with empathy, proposing the medal as a way to bring a piece of “home” to the wandering dead and securing Renn’s cooperation through compassion rather than authority.
character_moments.Bazgar: Takes a direct, no-nonsense approach—confirming the enemy in the old war and committing to laying Renn’s ancestor to rest, while also probing the Imperium’s use of necromancy.
character_moments.Marwen: Shows practical caution about the watchtower’s staffing and the broader threat, highlighting that the frontier isn’t fully safe even in peacetime.

summaries.factual_summary: Guided by Marwen’s attunement to the land (and watched by a lingering crow), the party reached a clifftop overlooking a small group of skeletons moving through dense brush below. They rappelled to a lower ledge and opened fire from range, dropping some undead before the survivors scattered into the forest, forcing a chaotic chase. In the pursuit, Sabriel used magic and Renn’s war medallion to identify and peacefully release Corwin Caldor, while Bazgar and Marwen finished off the remaining skeletons and gathered Corwin’s intact remains for return to the watchtower.
summaries.narrative_seed: From a wind-battered ledge above the eastern valley, the party watched pale shapes drift through wet undergrowth—soldiers long dead, still walking as if “home” were a direction you could follow. Their first strikes shattered the quiet and sent the undead shambling apart into the trees, turning a clean ambush into a frantic, splintered pursuit. When the medallion finally touched the right skeleton, the violence faltered into something gentler: a moment of recognition, a slackening jaw, and a spirit that seemed to finally let go.
key_events: Marwen led the party to a cliff vantage where they spotted a larger-than-expected group of undead (five skeletons partially obscured by shrubs).
Bazgar anchored a rope with his climbing kit and coordinated the descent to a mid-ledge, positioning the party for an opening volley.

The party initiated an ambush from the ledge, destroying one skeleton with radiant magic and dropping another with fire, prompting the remaining undead to scatter into the forest rather than press the fight.
Sabriel used Fey Step to get down quickly (taking a rough tumble on the rocky slope), then later used it again to propel Bazgar forward to intercept a fleeing skeleton.
Marwen used Jump to traverse the steep terrain and sprint after a fleeing skeleton, drawing its attention and narrowly avoiding a sword strike before being stabbed in the ensuing melee.
Sabriel magically compelled one skeleton to collapse and grovel, then confirmed it was Corwin Caldor (the target) and attempted to finish it without destroying the remains.
Corwin reacted to the war medallion—sadly reaching for it—allowing Sabriel to place it around his neck and release him without further damage to the body.
Bazgar destroyed another skeleton with a crushing warhammer blow, scattering bones; Marwen later collected useful undead bone fragments from the wreckage.
With Corwin’s remains intact, the party wrapped and carried the body back toward the watchtower to return him to Renn.

character_moments.Bazgar: Took charge of the dangerous descent with rope and climbing kit, then pivoted from battlefield bravado to respect—carefully lifting Corwin’s remains and adjusting his handling to be more reverent.
character_moments.Sabriel: Prioritized identification and mercy over efficiency: tried to locate Corwin, used the medallion as a lure, and ultimately laid the undead to rest by placing the chain on him rather than destroying the body.
character_moments.Marwen: Showed both impulsive courage and practiced ritual magic—racing ahead with Jump, then using a carefully spoken incantation and ash focus to unleash a close-range burst of flame; afterward, she quietly pocketed undead bone for future use.

summaries.factual_summary: The party returned to the eastern border patrol tower with Corwin Caldor’s intact remains and reassured the guards they had not burned or destroyed the body. Renn Caldor led them to a solitary, pre-dug gravesite up the mountain path, where the group assisted in the burial—Bazgar with labor and Marwen by magically moving earth. After quiet prayers, Renn thanked them for bringing his grandfather home to be laid to rest and paid the agreed reward plus a bonus for their care.
summaries.narrative_seed: Cold, wet air clung to the mountain approach as the tower guards met the party with wary relief, eyes flicking to the bundle of bones they carried. At a lonely gravesite above the post, steel and spellwork gave way to silence: a grave filled, a few murmured prayers, and a grieving scout standing over the earth that finally closed a 127-year-old wound. Gold changed hands, but the real weight in the scene was the stillness after duty was done.
key_events: The party arrived back at the border patrol tower and addressed the guards’ concern about the fire and whether Corwin’s remains had been damaged.
Renn guided the party to an isolated gravesite and accepted Corwin’s remains with a respectful gesture.
The party helped complete the burial, with Marwen using elemental magic to move and settle the soil while Bazgar assisted physically.
Renn performed quiet burial prayers, then thanked the party and paid them (reward plus bonus) before returning to the grave to contemplate.

character_moments.Marwen: Used elemental magic to gently and efficiently fill the grave, emphasizing respect and care in the burial rites.
character_moments.Sabriel: Deferred leadership of the conversation to Bazgar, letting the party present a unified, respectful front during the handoff and burial.

summaries.factual_summary: After the burial, the party regrouped near their resting spot by the border tower and discussed what to do next to fund a future mountain expedition. They learned expedition costs: a basic trip runs about 50 gp per person, while a higher, more difficult route costs about 100 gp per person and includes hiring a dwarven mountain guide. The party took a short rest to patch up and recover, then decided to pursue the goblin-raiding job later the same day since the goblins strike at dusk.
summaries.narrative_seed: With the grave freshly covered and Renn returning to his private grief, the party’s mood turned practical and easygoing as they counted coin and talked ambitions. Over a brief rest and quiet bandaging, they weighed the price of climbing higher into the mountains—better rewards, higher risk—and chose a nearer problem to solve first. As afternoon slid toward evening, they set their sights west, timing their move to meet the goblins at dusk.
key_events: The party discussed funding a future mountain expedition and learned the cost tiers: ~50 gp each for a basic expedition, or ~100 gp each for a higher-mountain expedition that includes a dwarven mountain guide.
The party took a short rest to recover from earlier injuries and conserve resources for another encounter the same day.
They chose to tackle the goblin raids next, noting the goblins typically strike at dusk—making the late afternoon timing advantageous.

character_moments.Sabriel: Emphasized the need to earn more money before major spending and supported the plan to handle goblins now and other work later.

summaries.factual_summary: The party traveled to the western farmlands near Redwick Farm and met the sheep farmer (name unclear in play; Maren/Meryn Redwick). He indicated the goblins were likely coming from the direction of a ruined keep in the rocky scrubland. After examining signs of repeated night raids, the party set a magical alarm as a safeguard and, through a slow but successful conversation, convinced the farmer to consider a negotiated arrangement rather than simple retaliation.
summaries.narrative_seed: In the brisk afternoon air, the hills west of Ardenford rolled out in quiet greens—too peaceful for a place being bled dry at dusk. The farmer’s wary, slow-spoken answers and the layered tracks in the grass pointed toward a broken keep on the horizon, where something small and hungry kept returning. By sundown, the party had laid a warding line and reframed the raids as a crude attempt at trade—setting the stage for a cautious approach instead of a slaughter.
key_events: The party met Maren/Meryn Redwick in the grazing hills and confirmed the goblin raids are tied to the ruined keep visible in the scrubland.
The party identified repeated goblin approach routes and signs the raids happen at night while the farmer sleeps, then set an Alarm near the flock as a backup warning.
Sabriel questioned the farmer about whether the goblins left anything behind and discovered they have been leaving “trash” that is actually meant as payment/treasure from the goblins’ perspective.
After extended discussion, the party persuaded the farmer to accept a negotiation-based plan (goblins as would-be traders/protectors) rather than insisting on a purely violent solution.

character_moments.Sabriel: Took the lead socially, reframing the raids as barter and patiently guiding the farmer to understand the goblins may think they are trading; she also offered him a small blessing once he agreed to the plan.
character_moments.Marwen: Acted cautiously by setting an Alarm ward near the flock as a contingency and shared her conclusions about the goblins’ timing and approach.
character_moments.Bazgar: Pushed for direct action toward the goblins’ suspected source (the keep) and offered to ‘loom’ as intimidation support, but largely let Sabriel handle the delicate negotiation setup.

summaries.location: Ruins/old keep near the sheep grazing hills (western scrublands)
summaries.goal: Approach the goblins to negotiate a deal to stop the sheep raids (and return their 'treasures')
npcs_present: Maren/Meryn Redwick (off-screen, back at the sheep)
summaries.notes: At sunset the party leaves the farmer and heads into the nearby ruins to speak with goblins, with Bazgar taking point in Orcish while the others hang back and prepare support.
summaries.factual_summary: At dusk, the party approached the western scrubland ruins to open negotiations with the goblins responsible for the sheep raids, bringing along the goblins’ collected “treasures” as leverage. Bazgar took point, calling out in Orcish and attempting to speak for the group while the others stayed back and tried to observe from a safer distance. A goblin scout challenged Bazgar’s identity and intentions; Bazgar leaned into a more intimidating, tribal-orc demeanor to be taken seriously. When Bazgar proposed a deal—goblins guard the sheep and receive a sheep as payment instead of raiding—the talks soured, and the goblins shifted toward hostility as the scene tipped into imminent violence.
summaries.narrative_seed: Evening shadows pooled between the broken stones of the old keep as Bazgar strode forward openly, voice carrying in harsh Orcish across the rubble. A goblin’s head appeared, suspicious and sharp-eyed, circling him like a scavenger testing a larger predator. For a moment, the offer of trade and a new arrangement hung in the cold air—then the goblins’ hunger and mistrust bared their teeth, and the ruins felt less like a meeting ground and more like a trap about to spring.
key_events: The party advanced to the ruined keep at sunset to negotiate, choosing an open approach rather than sneaking, and offering to return goblin “treasures” as part of the deal.
Bazgar hailed the goblins in Orcish and was met by a wary goblin who questioned why he traveled with humans and whether he was truly an orc.
Bazgar intimidated the goblin into treating him as a legitimate southern orc rather than a human, shifting his posture and tone to project dominance.
Bazgar proposed replacing raids with a payment arrangement: the goblins would guard the sheep and be given a sheep rather than stealing them.
Negotiations deteriorated as goblin hostility escalated, setting the stage for a fight in the ruins.

character_moments.Bazgar: Took the lead as translator and negotiator in Orcish, deliberately approaching without overt aggression, then pivoted into a more fearsome, tribal persona to command goblin respect when challenged.
character_moments.Sabriel: Supported the negotiation plan by urging the return of the goblins’ “treasures” to sweeten the offer and coordinated cautious backup while Bazgar went forward.
character_moments.Marwen: Tried to assess what the party knew about goblins and communication, then stayed back to avoid provoking the goblins while still attempting to monitor the situation.

summaries.factual_summary: Inside the goblin-held ruins, negotiations fully collapse when a goblin tries to snatch Bazgar’s axe, triggering an ambush and close-quarters fight. Marwen advances with fire magic while Sabriel supports with radiant magic and healing, and Bazgar holds the front line despite taking a hard hit from a scimitar-wielding goblin boss. Several goblins are killed in the skirmish, and the last surviving goblin attempts to surrender by calling itself a “good pet,” prompting the party to spare it and drive it off. With the immediate threat ended, the party discusses bringing proof of the goblins’ defeat back to the Redwick farm.
summaries.narrative_seed: Evening shadows and broken walls turn the old keep into a maze of sudden movement—small shapes darting, weapons flashing, and improvised junk swung like clubs. Firelight blooms in Marwen’s hand as Sabriel’s silver radiance drops a goblin where it stands, while Bazgar’s fury and discipline keep the line from collapsing. When the last goblin realizes it’s alone, it grins up through sharp teeth and begs in the only surrender it knows: “Good pet.”
key_events: A goblin attempts to steal Bazgar’s axe, and the ambush erupts into open combat inside the ruins.
Marwen pushes forward with flame while Sabriel strikes with Sacred Flame and then uses Healing Word to stabilize Marwen after she’s badly hurt.
A scimitar-wielding goblin boss lands a heavy blow on Bazgar, forcing Bazgar to rally and then cut down the attacker.
Marwen unleashes a cone of fire that incinerates two goblins at once, swinging the fight decisively in the party’s favor.
The final goblin surrenders by insisting it is a “good pet,” and Sabriel physically calms the moment by petting it, stopping Bazgar from finishing it off.
Bazgar warns the surrendered goblin in Orcish to never return; it flees, and Bazgar takes a goblin head as proof for the quest.

character_moments.Bazgar: Refuses to be disarmed, fights through being bloodied by the goblin boss, then pulls up short mid-charge when he sees Sabriel petting the surrendering goblin—choosing restraint over momentum before sending it away with a warning.
character_moments.Marwen: Steps into the chaos with flame ready, takes a painful hit, then answers with overwhelming fire that drops multiple goblins and ends the immediate threat.
character_moments.Sabriel: Balances offense and mercy—burns down a goblin with divine radiance, heals Marwen back from the brink, then de-escalates the finale by accepting a clumsy goblin surrender and sparing its life.

summaries.factual_summary: After clearing the goblin threat, the party returns to Redwick Farm in the evening to report that the raids have ended. They present proof of the goblins’ defeat and confirm that some surviving sheep were recovered and brought back. Maren Redwick pays the agreed reward of 70 gp and, grateful for the returned animals, adds two wheels of sharp cheese and an invitation to the next harvest festival. With the job concluded, the party decides to head back toward town to rest at the tavern.
summaries.narrative_seed: Evening settles over the western farmlands as the party trudges back to Redwick Farm, bruised but relieved, carrying grim proof that the raiders won’t be coming again. Maren’s tension breaks into grateful relief when she sees her sheep returned, and she presses coin and sharp farmhouse cheese into their hands like a blessing. With the hills quiet again, the group turns their thoughts from blood and stone to warmth, beds, and a tavern hearth in Ardenford.

summaries.factual_summary: The party returns to The Wayward Compass for the night, orders dinner, and settles in to rest after the goblin job. Bazgar asks Thorgrim Ledger-Scar for local food recommendations and briefly probes him about Garhammer ties, but Thorgrim shuts the topic down. Over the meal, the party debriefs their success and intentionally shares personal background and motivations, agreeing to rest and tackle the posted spider problem in the morning.
summaries.narrative_seed: Warm firelight and the murmur of Ardenford’s Middle Tier crowd wrap the Wayward Compass in a lived-in calm as the party finally slows down. Between plates of fresh-caught fish, mutton, bread, and sweet spreads, guarded strangers become something closer to allies—sharing ambitions, old wounds, and reasons for chasing ruins. The night stays easy and conversational… right up until unfamiliar Imperium colors begin to enter the tavern.

Bazgar speaks with Thorgrim Ledger-Scar for a local cuisine recommendation and asks about Garhammer connections; Thorgrim gives little away and ends the line of questioning.
Bazgar proposes the group get to know each other better to improve teamwork; the party begins sharing personal details and motivations.
The group agrees on the plan: rest tonight, then go deal with the spider infestation job in the morning.

summaries.factual_summary: Three clearly identifiable Calderon Imperium traders entered The Wayward Compass and moved with disciplined, uniform-like coordination, ordering the same food and seating themselves together while watching the party. Bazgar’s mood immediately soured at their presence, and the party chose to head upstairs to avoid escalating tension. As Bazgar passed them, he spat on the floor in their direction, prompting one trader to covertly attempt to trip him as he went by.
summaries.narrative_seed: The tavern’s warmth tightened into a cold, watchful silence when the Imperium traders filed in—gray-clad, synchronized, and unmistakably foreign in Ardenford’s loose, lived-in chaos. Their eyes lingered on the party like an inspection, and Bazgar’s simmering resentment broke the fragile peace with a small, deliberate insult. The night teetered on the edge of a public incident as the traders answered contempt with a quiet, calculated shove of the foot.
key_events: Three Calderon Imperium traders entered the Wayward Compass, ordered in unison, sat together, and kept watching the party.
The party decided to turn in early to avoid trouble, but Bazgar spat toward the traders while passing, and one trader attempted to trip him.

summaries.factual_summary: In the common room of The Wayward Compass, Bazgar is covertly tripped by one of the Calderon Imperium traders and mocked. Bazgar responds by hauling the instigator into the open floor space and starting a bare-knuckle fight under Thorgrim Ledger-Scar’s “no weapons” tavern rule. After Bazgar drops the first trader, the other two jump in, but Bazgar beats them back as well. Thorgrim ends the incident by offering free beer to both sides as a binding peace accord, and the Imperium traders accept.
summaries.narrative_seed: Night tension snaps into violence as a disciplined Imperium trio turns a petty trip into a public humiliation. Bazgar, refusing steel but not refusing blood, drags the offender into Thorgrim’s deliberately cleared fighting space and answers laughter with fists. When the traders’ friends swarm in, the tavern keeper doesn’t intervene—he waits until the lesson is taught, then seals the room’s fragile order with a silent, mandatory toast: free beer, and the matter dies here.
key_events: A Calderon Imperium trader trips Bazgar as he passes, and the trio laughs at him in the common room.
Bazgar grabs the instigator and forces him into the tavern’s open floor space to settle it without weapons.
The instigator attempts a cheap shot from behind, but Bazgar turns the momentum into a full brawl.
Bazgar knocks out the first trader; the other two Imperium traders rush in and land a few hits before Bazgar drops one and drives the last out of the fight.
Thorgrim Ledger-Scar offers free beer to both parties as his peace accord; the Imperium traders accept, ending the confrontation inside the tavern.

character_moments.Thorgrim Ledger-Scar: Enforces his Compass-style order by allowing the weaponless scuffle to play out and then compelling a ceasefire through his “free beer” peace accord, making it clear the dispute cannot be carried beyond his bar.
character_moments.Marwen: Stays out of the brawl, observing the Imperium tension and later focusing on calming, private ritual practice rather than escalating the conflict.
character_moments.Sabriel: Maintains a watchful, disciplined posture—positioning herself as the last to retire and first awake—signaling caution about further Imperium trouble.

summaries.factual_summary: In the morning at The Wayward Compass, Marwyn approaches a friendly elf in the common room and questions him for intel about mounting an expedition into the nearby mountains. The elf introduces himself as Elarion Faenwynd, an archivist tied to the Concordance Library who keeps a rune/ruin catalog ledger, and he offers practical guidance on where to start looking for smaller ruin sites and how to pursue further research through the library. He also points the party toward local suppliers—weapon work, alchemy, and arcane wares—and advises that the most reliable mountain guides are oath-bound dwarves, though they are harder to locate than other options.
summaries.narrative_seed: Morning light and hearth-warmth fill the Compass as Marwyn simply sits down with a stranger and turns curiosity into opportunity. Elarion Faenwynd—ink-stained, reserved, and quietly confident—proves to be exactly the sort of person who knows how the city’s secrets are filed away, and he answers with the calm precision of someone used to turning questions into expeditions. summaries.factual_summary: The party infiltrated the web-choked abandoned lumber camp and found two human-shaped cocoons hanging in the trees, one still moving. Bazgar tried to sneak in first but got snagged in the webbing and drew the attention of a giant spider. Marwen used magic to speak with the spider and, with threats of fire, negotiated it into retreating and leaving the captives behind; a newly hatching spiderling attacked Marwen and was killed, and the remaining eggs were burned. The party cut down the cocoons, confirmed one worker dead and one alive but comatose, stabilized the survivor, secured the camp’s tools, and prepared to return to Ardenford to report to Gareth Thorne.
summaries.narrative_seed: Morning light hit the camp’s webbing like false snowfall, but the forest around it felt dead-quiet—until the party spotted two cocooned bodies swaying above the ground. Bazgar’s careful approach turned into a tense standoff when the spider noticed him, and Marwen’s calm, unsettling negotiation—backed by conjured flame—drove the predator away without a full battle. Even so, the lair’s hunger lingered in the eggs, and the party left with smoke on the air, one life saved, and uneasy questions about mercy versus safety.
key_events: The party approached the abandoned lumber camp and discovered two cocooned workers hanging in the trees, one apparently still alive.
Sabriel cast Bless on the group before the approach, preparing them for the spider’s poison and an imminent fight.
Bazgar attempted to sneak closer but became stuck in webbing, alerting the visible giant spider and forcing a tense face-to-face moment.
Marwen used Speak with Animals to communicate with the spider and threatened it with fire to force it to abandon the camp and leave the captives.
A spider egg hatched into an aggressive spiderling near Marwen; Marwen killed it and then burned the remaining eggs to prevent more hatchlings.
The party cut down and unwrapped the cocoons, finding one worker dead and the other alive but comatose and poisoned; Sabriel stabilized the survivor with divine magic.
They searched the camp and recovered the lumber crew’s tools from beneath webbing, then loaded the bodies onto a cart pulled by Lear for transport back to town.
After a perimeter check, the party concluded the immediate threat was gone, though they debated whether the driven-off spider might return or prey elsewhere.

Marwen’s research turns from orderly scholarship to a stumble into something that shouldn’t be on any shelf: a beautiful holy volume that refuses to show its words. With temptation winning over caution, she slips it away, carrying a secret that may be older—and more dangerous—than the questions that brought her here.

While researching oldest religions for Sabriel, Marwen finds an uncatalogued, ornate holy book whose pages appear blank; she casts Detect Magic and confirms it is magical (conjuration) and feels distinctly divine rather than arcane.

Marwen researches the drow: public records describe classic drow society (raiders, matron mothers, spider cults) and confirm they vanished at the start of the Age of Conflict; she learns Lolth is believed to still exist, but the disappearance of the drow led to a widespread purge/massacre of Lolth’s surface worshippers, leaving no known active cults in the public record.

Sabriel shares deeper elven historical framing: the Age of Ash and Silence followed the end of the Ancients, preceding the Age of Reclamation; she shows sketches of a colossal ancient city-ruin that appears to have fallen and later eroded into what is now known as the Lone Mountain.

summaries.narrative_seed: Warm firelight and tavern noise can’t soften the unease of a book that insists it is Sabriel’s while offering nothing but blank pages. key_events: Marwen quietly places the mysterious starburst-sealed holy book before Sabriel and insists she keep its transfer secret.

The group argues over strategy—Bazgar pushes for riskier, higher-reward ruins, while Marwen and Sabriel advocate starting in the valley; they settle on beginning with the valley ruin and building resources and teamwork.
